description.plain:
AC/DC is an Australian rock band, formed in 1973 by brothers Malcolm and Angus Young, who have remained the sole constant members (though Malcolm left prior to the recording of 2015’s Rock or Bust due to medical issues). Commonly classified as hard rock, they are considered pioneers of heavy metal and are sometimes classified as such, though they themselves have always classified their music as simply “rock and roll”. To date, they are one of the highest grossing bands of all time.

But when their vocalist, Bon Scott died after a night out in London, the group wanted to disband. That didn’t happen. Instead, Scott was replaced with Brian Johnson. Their only statement to Scott’s Death was that he had “drunken himself to Death.”

Malcolm and Angus Young came up with the band name after their sister saw “AC/DC” on the side of an electric sewing machine, and ended up asking, “Why not AC/DC?”

As of 2010, AC/DC had sold more than 200 million albums worldwide, including 71 million albums in the United States alone. 1980’s Back in Black, the first album with singer Brian Johnson, has sold an estimated 49 million units worldwide, making it the third highest-selling album by any artist, and the second highest-selling album by any band, behind Pink Floyd’s Dark Side of The Moon and Michael Jackson’s Thriller. The album has sold 22 million units in the U.S. alone, where it is the fifth-highest-selling album of all-time. AC/DC ranked fourth on VH1’s list of the “100 Greatest Artists of Hard Rock” and was named the seventh “Greatest Heavy Metal Band of All Time” by MTV. In 2004, AC/DC was ranked number 72 in the Rolling Stone list of the “100 Greatest Artists of All Time”. In 2010, AC/DC were ranked number 23 on the VH1 list of the “100 Greatest Artists of All Time”.

Members:
-Angus Young – lead guitar (1973–present)
- Cliff Williams – bass guitar, backing vocals (1977–2016[retired following the Rock or Bust Tour])
- Stevie Young – rhythm guitar, backing vocals (1988 [touring member], 2014–present)
- Chris Slade – drums (1989–1994, 2015–present)
- Brian Johnson – lead and backing vocals (1980–2016 [Indefinite Hiatus])
- Axl Rose – lead vocals (2016 [touring member])

Former members
- Malcolm Young – rhythm guitar, backing vocals (1973–2014)
- Dave Evans – lead vocals (1973–1974)
- Bon Scott – lead vocals (1974–1980)
- Mark Evans – bass guitar (1975–1977)
- Phil Rudd – drums (1975–1983, 1994–2015)
- Simon Wright – drums (1983–1989)

songs.full_title: Back in Black by AC/DC

body.plain: “Back In Black” is the title track off AC/DC’s first album with Brian Johnson, and became its third single. The song is a tribute to deceased frontman Bon Scott. When Brian Johnson was told to write a song, the members said, “It can’t be morbid – it has to be for Bon and it has to be a celebration.” And so they wrote it from Bon’s perpective. The song has since become a mainstay of their concerts, and the riff is one of the most iconic in rock music – for instance, it was the first song Kurt Cobain learned to play, at the age of 14.

songs.full_title: Thunderstruck by AC/DC

body.plain: “Thunderstruck” was released as the lead single off of The Razors Edge. It is one of the most well known and popular AC/DC songs and has been performed at every AC/DC concert since its release. It is the only song the band recorded in the 90s that remains a staple in every tour since its recording.

songs.full_title: Highway to Hell by AC/DC

body.plain:
For all it’s heavy riffing and dark imagery, “Highway to Hell” is a depiction of something altogether more lighthearted. A typical move, considering the overriding sense of humor and fun the band proudly held onto.

Bon Scott sings about how his life is a wild ride comparable to a highway to Hell (in a bit of tragic irony, he died by drinking himself to death a year after the album’s release).

Released as the first single off the album, it is one of AC/DC’s most popular and famous tracks, it has been played at almost all of AC/DC’s live shows since its release.

A lot of people have noticed the duality this song shares with another monumental rock song from the same time period; Led Zeppelin’s “Stairway To Heaven”. Both huge hits and eternal evergreens, they contradict each other both metaphorically Stairway/highway + heaven/hell and musically. One being a long soft ballad, that other being an uptempo, hard-hitting short rock song.

annotatable.title: You Shook Me All Night Long

description_annotation.fragment: You Shook Me All Night Long

body.plain:
“You Shook Me All Night Long” was released as the lead single off Back in Black and is one of AC/DC’s signature songs. In the song, the lead singer Brian Johnson relates the story of a night with a beautiful woman.

It is one of the band’s top 40 singles in the United States of America, reaching number 35 on the USA’s Hot 100 pop singles chart in 1980. It placed at No. 10 on VH1’s list of “The 100 Greatest Songs of the 80s”. It was also No. 1 on VH1’s “Top Ten AC/DC Songs”. Guitar World placed “You Shook Me All Night Long” number 80 on their “100 Greatest Guitar Solos” list.

songs.full_title: T.N.T. by AC/DC

body.plain:
AC/DC’s T.N.T. is a single that was released in 1976 taken from the albums, T.N.T. and High Voltage. The songs lyrics depict a man’s tale of a day of his life, beginning in the sunset on the News, starting fights, being wanted, and not being messed with by the town folk.

A staple in 70’s Rock Age, the song has appeared throughout the media, being heard in the T.V. Show, That 70’s Show, in the movie Napoleon Dynamite, and being featured as one of the tracks available in the game Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater 4.

It was a big hit and peaked No. 11 on the Australian Kent Music Report Singles Chart. The band always plays it at their concerts.

annotatable.link_title: Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap by AC/DC
annotatable.title: Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap

body.plain:
The title track off of AC/DC’s second album has a hitman promoting his killing-on-a-budget services to a (or multiple) girls.

A couple of different LP versions of the song exist. One is the edit that is on the UK and US version (the US version did not get until 1981) and the Australian version, which is the longest of the two. Later CD re-releases comes with the long edition of the song.

songs.full_title: Hells Bells by AC/DC

body.plain:
This is the first track and second single from the album Back In Black. The song was written to commemorate the death of AC/DC’s former lead singer, Bon Scott.

The bell heard throughout the song was created by John Taylor Bellfounders in Loughborough from 2,000-pounds of cast bronze. Originally used during the 1980 Back in Black tour, it was made as is a replica of the Denison Bell, which the band first attempted to record for the song – this plan was abandoned after causing too much disruption to pigeons nesting in the bell tower.

The bell includes an engraving of the AC/DC logo and is branded with the title, “Hells Bell.”

songs.full_title: Shoot to Thrill by AC/DC

body.plain:
The second track off of Back in Black is pretty sexual in its tone. The singer utilizes the metaphor of a gun to describe his male sexual organ, in which his climaxing is referred to as “pulling the trigger”.

Iron Man likes the song in a more literal sense (after all he shoots, usually repulsor beams, even if Tony Stark is also a ladies' man), hence he twice using it to introduce himself.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qTchfvLfX0o

songs.full_title: It's a Long Way to the Top (If You Wanna Rock n' Roll) by AC/DC

annotatable.link_title: It’s a Long Way to the Top (If You Wanna Rock n’ Roll) by AC/DC
annotatable.title: It's a Long Way to the Top (If You Wanna Rock n' Roll)

description_annotation.fragment: It’s a Long Way to the Top (If You Wanna Rock n’ Roll)

body.plain:
A song about the hardships of rock n'roll bands trying to become big and famous. Many musicians work in bad conditions, before they get famous and lead a life of luxury. A lot of badly paid gigs in sketchy places (when you’re  being cheated and thus not paid), being on the road all the time in cheap modes of transport, encountering all kinds of hardships like hostile audiences, etc. Features one of the few instruments in AC/DC’s ouvre outside of guitars, bass and drums: a bagpipe solo!

This song was included in the 1975' album T.N.T. (which was only released in Australia) and in 1976’s High Voltage (the international version, not to be confused with 1975’s High Voltage, which was also only released in Australia). It served as the second single off the T.N.T. album.

songs.full_title: Whole Lotta Rosie by AC/DC

body.plain:
“Whole Lotta Rosie” was released as the third and last single off Let There Be Rock. This song is a purportedly true story about one time frontman Bon Scott was staying in a hotel in Melbourne and when he went out to check out the pubs, he ran into this obese Tazmanian woman, named Rosie. She invited him back to her place for a party and when he got there, she closed the door and laid herself on top of him. She was “too big to say no to”, in Bon’s words, “so I just had to succumb, I had to do it. My God, I wish I hadn’t”.

Bon has said she was about 6'2" and anywhere from 19 stone (266 lbs), as said in the song, to 21 stone, 11 lbs (305 lbs).

Ever since the 1991 Razor’s Edge tour, when the song is played live, “Rosie”, a huge blow-up doll with a voluminous body shape, joins the band on stage.

album.full_title: Let There Be Rock  by AC/DC
album.name: Let There Be Rock

songs.full_title: Let There Be Rock by AC/DC

annotatable.link_title: Let There Be Rock by AC/DC
annotatable.title: Let There Be Rock

body.plain:
“Let There Be Rock” can be described as the most rocking bible passages ever! The album’s title track was released as second single and has frequently been a part of AC/DC’s setlists. It was the set closer before “For Those About to Rock” took that spot, leading “Let There Be Rock” to be the song played before the encore. To highlight this, and mark the song as one of the peaks of the concert, Angus Young would be left alone on the stage after the end of the second verse to throw himself into a guitar solo that often broke 10 minutes (as seen in their various live recordings). Thus truly, there would be ROCK!

“Let There Be Rock” is a playable song in the music video game Rock Band 2.

songs.full_title: Touch Too Much by AC/DC

body.plain:
“Touch Too Much” was released as the third and final single off Highway To Hell, a praise to a woman, who touched Bon Scott in unusual and really pleasing ways.

Since it’s inception in 1977, the song had went through many changes from arrangement to lyrics before the final version of the song was selected to be on the album. The final version was then performed by AC/DC on the BBC music show Top of the Pops a few days before lead singer Bon Scott died, in 1980.

Given Top of the Pops features playback, the song wasn’t properly performed featured in concert until 2016, given once they auditioned Axl Rose to sub in for Brian Johnson, it was one of the songs he showed off. (according to Angus, he went “Can you play this one?”, and the band went “No, we never learned it” as they had never attempted to play it live.)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PY4FATpK9UI

songs.full_title: For Those About to Rock (We Salute You) by AC/DC

annotatable.link_title: For Those About to Rock (We Salute You) by AC/DC
annotatable.title: For Those About to Rock (We Salute You)

description_annotation.fragment: For Those About to Rock (We Salute You)

body.plain:
“For Those About to Rock (We Salute You)” was released as the second and last single off of For Those About To Rock. The epic rocker is an ode to every rock n' roller in the world and one of AC/DC’s signature songs. The title and central lyric of the song are based on an ancient salute used by Roman prisoners to be executed in the Colosseum, “Ave, Caesar, morituri te salutant” (“Hail Caesar, we who are about to die, salute you.”).

During live concerts, this song is often played as the last encore. During the performance of the song, cannons are rolled onto the stage and fired.



The single’s B-side contains an edited live version of “Let There Be Rock,” recorded in Landover, Maryland, in late-1981. The video to “For Those About to Rock (We Salute You)” was filmed at that same concert.

The song was later included on AC/DC’s first soundtrack album, Who Made Who, released in 1986 for the Stephen King film Maximum Overdrive.

songs.full_title: Rock N' Roll Train by AC/DC

annotatable.link_title: Rock N’ Roll Train by AC/DC
annotatable.title: Rock N' Roll Train

body.plain:
“Rock N' Roll Train” was released as the first single off Black Ice. It marked the end of AC/DC’s eight year hiatus. The longest in the band’s lifetime.

First composed with the title “Runaway Train” and even considered as a possible title track for the album during production, it was changed because there are too many songs/records with that title.  It still inspired the set decoration for the Black Ice World Tour, featuring a huge locomotive.

The success of “Rock N' Roll Train” even made the band play it on the Rock or Bust tour – the first post-“Thunderstruck” song featured in a tour besides the ones in the promoted album.

album.full_title: Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap [Australian Edition] by AC/DC
album.name: Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap [Australian Edition]

body.plain:
AC/DC is an Australian rock band, formed in 1973 by brothers Malcolm and Angus Young, who have remained the sole constant members (though Malcolm left prior to the recording of 2015’s Rock or Bust due to medical issues). Commonly classified as hard rock, they are considered pioneers of heavy metal and are sometimes classified as such, though they themselves have always classified their music as simply “rock and roll”. To date, they are one of the highest grossing bands of all time.

But when their vocalist, Bon Scott died after a night out in London, the group wanted to disband. That didn’t happen. Instead, Scott was replaced with Brian Johnson. Their only statement to Scott’s Death was that he had “drunken himself to Death.”

Malcolm and Angus Young came up with the band name after their sister saw “AC/DC” on the side of an electric sewing machine, and ended up asking, “Why not AC/DC?”

As of 2010, AC/DC had sold more than 200 million albums worldwide, including 71 million albums in the United States alone. 1980’s Back in Black, the first album with singer Brian Johnson, has sold an estimated 49 million units worldwide, making it the third highest-selling album by any artist, and the second highest-selling album by any band, behind Pink Floyd’s Dark Side of The Moon and Michael Jackson’s Thriller. The album has sold 22 million units in the U.S. alone, where it is the fifth-highest-selling album of all-time. AC/DC ranked fourth on VH1’s list of the “100 Greatest Artists of Hard Rock” and was named the seventh “Greatest Heavy Metal Band of All Time” by MTV. In 2004, AC/DC was ranked number 72 in the Rolling Stone list of the “100 Greatest Artists of All Time”. In 2010, AC/DC were ranked number 23 on the VH1 list of the “100 Greatest Artists of All Time”.

Members:
-Angus Young – lead guitar (1973–present)
- Cliff Williams – bass guitar, backing vocals (1977–2016[retired following the Rock or Bust Tour])
- Stevie Young – rhythm guitar, backing vocals (1988 [touring member], 2014–present)
- Chris Slade – drums (1989–1994, 2015–present)
- Brian Johnson – lead and backing vocals (1980–2016 [Indefinite Hiatus])
- Axl Rose – lead vocals (2016 [touring member])

Former members
- Malcolm Young – rhythm guitar, backing vocals (1973–2014)
- Dave Evans – lead vocals (1973–1974)
- Bon Scott – lead vocals (1974–1980)
- Mark Evans – bass guitar (1975–1977)
- Phil Rudd – drums (1975–1983, 1994–2015)
- Simon Wright – drums (1983–1989)
